content: I say enlist, but I am predisposed to say that as an elisted man. Greywolfghost makes a good point about doing both. I know in the submarine service we had a great deal more respect for officers that were prior enlisted. Not to mean other officers were not respected or anything like that, but there were many times a new officer right out of college would say to do "X", and we would turn and look at our chief and LPO first... I reccomend enlisting for atleast one term, you get to see how things work on that side, which will make you a better officer if you latter decide to go to OCS or one of the various enlisted to officer programs. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: For medical personnel, the situation's a little different. If nursing is really what you want to do, go for it. The military could use you. Look into going to school first, and getting the Navy to foot the bill while you complete your coursework full-time. The Army has programs that will do this, I'm pretty sure the Navy does too. Talk to a recruiter. You could possibly even serve as a reservist while you went to school, which would give you that taste of the military immediately.
